title: 110_hr550
content: The Act titled "Securing America's Energy Independence Act of 2007" extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy property and qualified fuel cell property. The Act extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy property and qualified fuel cell property by amending certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Clause (i) of section 48(a)(3)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include equipment using solar energy for electricity generation, heating, cooling, hot water provision, solar process heat, and advanced energy storage systems. Solar lighting equipment now includes solar hybrid lighting. Solar lighting equipment now includes solar hybrid lighting systems that use solar energy to illuminate structures with fiber-optic distributed sunlight. Solar photovoltaic energy property credit is determined solely by kilowatt capacity. Solar lighting equipment now includes solar hybrid lighting systems that illuminate structures using fiber-optic distributed sunlight. Amendments have been made to the solar photovoltaic energy property credit, with the credit now determined solely by kilowatt capacity. The energy credit for solar photovoltaic energy property is $1,500 for each half kilowatt of capacity when used to generate electricity and placed in service during the taxable year. The energy credit for solar photovoltaic energy property is $1,500 for each half kilowatt of capacity when used to generate electricity and placed in service during the taxable year. Special rules apply to rehabilitated or subsidized property. The rules for property described in paragraph (3)(A)(i) are amended to apply to specified credits against the Alternative Minimum Tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allow specified credits against the Alternative Minimum Tax, including the investment credit under section 46(2). The effective date for these amendments is January 1, 2007. The amendments made by this section will take effect on January 1, 2007, except for those made by subsection (c) which will apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006. Extension and modification of credit for residential energy efficient property. Extension and modification of the credit for residential energy efficient property include amending the termination date to 2016, removing the 30 percent allowance for solar electric property, and setting a maximum credit of $1,500 for each half kilowatt in a taxable year. The maximum credit allowed for qualified solar electric property expenditures is $1,500 per half kilowatt of installed capacity, $2,000 for qualified solar water heating property expenditures, and $500 per half kilowatt of capacity for qualified fuel cell property. The maximum credit for qualified solar electric property expenditures is $1,500 per half kilowatt of installed capacity, $2,000 for qualified solar water heating property expenditures, and $500 per half kilowatt of capacity for qualified fuel cell property. Definitions for qualified solar water heating and photovoltaic property expenditures are also provided. Expenditure amendments in section 25D(d) of the Internal Revenue Code include allowing for heating, cooling, or providing hot water. Definition of qualified photovoltaic property expenditure now includes advanced energy storage systems. Credit against alternative minimum tax is allowed under section 25D(b). The amendment in section 25D(b) of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a credit against the alternative minimum tax, limiting the credit to the excess of regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55 over the sum of other allowable credits. The amendment in section 25D(b) of the Internal Revenue Code limits the credit against the alternative minimum tax to the excess of regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55 over the sum of other allowable credits. Carryforward of any excess credit to the succeeding taxable year is also allowed. The excess credit from one taxable year can be carried forward to the next year under section 25D of the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments in various sections allow for the carryforward of unused credits to future taxable years. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding sections 25D and 25B for tax credits. These changes apply to expenditures after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4. 3-YEAR ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION PERIOD FOR SOLAR ENERGY PROPERTY AND FUEL CELL PROPERTY. The amendment to section 168(e)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code allows for accelerated depreciation of certain types of property, including solar energy and fuel cell property. The amendment to section 168(e)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code allows for accelerated depreciation of certain types of property, including solar energy and fuel cell property. A conforming amendment in section 168(e)(3)(B)(vi)(I) specifies that wind energy would be described in the same way as solar energy under certain conditions. The amendments made by this section apply to wind energy in the same way as solar energy, effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2006.
